Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Uptake of Research-Based Instructional Strategies in Undergraduate Chemistry, Mathematics, & Physics
Award.AbstractNarration: It is well documented that the use of Research-Based Instructional Strategies (RBIS) significantly improves learning and retention of students in undergraduate courses in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Yet, there are few large-scale efforts to document the use of RBIS and to explain why they are not more widely used by STEM faculty. This project aims to fill the knowledge gap by examining the use of RBIS and identifying factors that influence implementation of RBIS in undergraduate STEM education. During Phase I of the study, the project team will survey faculty who teach introductory STEM courses in mathematics (Calculus I & II), Chemistry (General Chemistry), and Physics (Introductory Quantitative Physics). The faculty will include people from four types of institutions (associate's colleges, baccalaureate colleges, master's colleges, and doctoral universities). During Phase II, a subset of survey respondents will be invited to participate in interviews that are designed to investigate important themes identified in the survey. The primary aims of the research project are to (1) build capacity to document changes in the implementation of RBIS; (2) estimate the importance of individuals, departments, institutions, and disciplines in shaping instructional decisions to implement RBIS; and (3) test a set of hypotheses on how and why instructors use RBIS. <br/><br/>The national survey followed by in-depth interviews will establish baseline data for mathematics and chemistry faculty, and will provide an updated and extended snapshot following a 2008 survey of physics faculty. Based on the nested structure of the data, hierarchical linear modeling will be used to examine the quantitative survey data. Qualitative interview data will be analyzed to identify the individual factors, themes, or patterns of factors influencing the implementation of RBIS. The design is well-suited for explaining the quantitative significance (or non-significance) of the results and for providing a more nuanced, qualitative understanding of the implementation of RBIS and reasons for their use across STEM disciplines and types of institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objectives of this project were to (1) document the extent to which research-based instructional strategies (RBIS) are currently being used in introductory undergraduate math, chemistry, and physics courses; (2) understand what influences instructional practice by looking at individual, department, institution, discipline level factors; and (3) test hypotheses that have emerged from prior research about how and why instructors are using RBIS.


With regards to (1), we were able to collect survey responses from 3,769 recent instructors of postsecondary General Chemistry, Calculus I and II, and Introductory Quantitative Physics. Respondents came from 851 distinct institutions across the United States, including two-year colleges, four-year colleges, and research universities. Looking at the specific RBIS respondents reported using, as well as descriptions of how they spend their time in class, has allowed us a better understanding of the current (as of 2019) state of math and science instruction nationally. For instance, on average, instructors in physics report lecturing for 54% of class time, 59% in chemistry, and 56% in mathematics. This snapshot allows us to better understand the ways in which efforts to shift instruction have succeeded. It also serves as a foundation for our additional research efforts (e.g., objective 2). 


With regards to (2), our multilevel models allowed us to identify several malleable factors that influence instructional practice (specifically that are related to a decreased use of lecturing). Classroom space (i.e., conducive to group work or not), participation in scholarship of teaching and learning/discipline-based education research activities, and participation in teaching-related workshops have the largest association with decreased time lecturing. Results from this analysis support the role of personal and contextual factors in choices to enact active learning pedagogies. Additionally, this research has supported the development of recommendations for how instructional faculty members and institutional leaders can justify and argue for physical and structural changes that support pedagogical reforms. Additionally, based on interviews with 27 instructors in 16 departments we have developed a model that highlights the relevant characteristics of chemistry, math, and physics departments that have high use of active learning instruction in their introductory courses. According to this model, there are four main characteristics of such departments (motivated people, knowledge about teaching, opportunities, and cultures and structures that support active learning) and two positive feedback loops.

 

With regards to (3), our research showed some consistency with commonly held beliefs about the impact of (a) class size, in that very large classes use more lecture; (b) classroom setup, in that traditional classrooms use more lecture than ones built for active learning; (c) experiences as a student, in that instructors who took classes taught using RBIS use less lecture than those who did not; and (d) research activity, in that instructors with very high research productivity lecture more than others. Mixed results came from an investigation of the role of student evaluations: when assessment of teaching effectiveness is important, instructors at institutions with less emphasis on student evaluations report more active learning. We found no evidence of impact on teaching practices based on the instructor’s security of employment (e.g., tenure status). These findings have implications for institutional priority-setting in service of increasing the use of RBIS in undergraduate courses.
